div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Grand Rapids Herald, September 23, 1928
div1.p:
THE GRAND RAPIDS HERALD.
SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1928

BODIES OF DEAN AND
COMRADES MAY REST
IN ARLINGTON PLOT

Gen. Pershing in Letter to Ed-
win F. Sweet Pays Tribute
to Hero

A. E. F. CHIEF CALLS HIM
“FIRST OF NOBLE BAND”

Announcement that congress is to
act upon a proposal providing for a
plot in Arlington National cemetery
for the burial of Maj. Walter Reed
and the soldier heroes of the yellow
fever experiment in Cuba following
the Spanish-American war, includ-
ing Pvt. William H. Dean of Grand
Rapids, is contained in a letter
from Gen. John J. Pershing to Ed-
win F. Sweet.

Mr. Sweet is a member of the
committee in charge of plans for
dedication of the Dean memorial
bridge across the Grand river at
Fulton st., next Saturday afternoon.

Pvt. Dean is referred to by Gen.
Pershing as “that simple cavalry-
man, who was the first of the noble
band of volunteers from the ranks
of the American army in Cuba to
suffer an attack of experimental
yellow fever.”
“First of Noble Band”

“I am gratified to have the oppor-
tunity to pay my tribute of respect
to that simple cavalryman. Pvt.
William H. Dean, Troop B, 7th
Cavalry, who was the first of the
noble band of volunteers from the
ranks of the American army in
Cuba to suffer an attack of ex-
perimental yellow fever,” Gen.
Pershing writes.

“He was the XY of Maj. Walter
Reed's Prelimniary Notes on the
transmission of yellow fever and,
although Dr. Carroll's attack pre-
ceded his, it was his case that car-
ried conviction to the minds of
Reed and the other members of the
yellow fever board.

“A bill was introduced at the last
session of congress providnig for
a plot in the Arlington ‘national
cemetery for the burial of the sol-
dier heroes of the fight against yel-
low fever, and the erection of a
fitting monument to them. The
surgeon-general of the army has
indorsed this proposal as follows:

“‘The episode of the demonstra-
tion by the board, of which Maj.
Walter Reed was the head, of the
method of transmission of yellow
fever was one of the most dramatic,
as well as one of the most import-
ant achievements in the history of
medicine.

“‘The success of the investigation
depended upon experiments upon
human beings, as at that time no
animal had been found which was
susceptible to this disease, and the
willingness with which, when these
experiments were authorized by the
military governor. Gen. Leonard
Wood, American soldiers came for-
ward and volunteered to undergo
them, gives an unusual and striking
character to the story of the
achievement.
“Benefits Inestimable”

“‘The benefits which have flowed
from the work of this board are
inestimable. This continent is now
free from a fatal and dreaded dis-
ease which had periodically invaded
our country for two hundred years
before, wasting the lives and wreck-
ing the prosperity of our southern
states.

“‘Trade has been released from
costly quarantines by land and sea
which before had tied up our com-
merce. Cuba and our West Indian
possessions have become safe. The
construction of the Panama canal
has been made possible.

“‘In view of these facts, a monu-
ment in our national cemetery to
the man who conceived this great
work, and to the men who aided
in its accomplishment, seems most
appropriate and desirable. The
erection of this monument seems
the more necessary because Walter
Reed died before there had been
sufficient demonstration of the
magnitude of his service to the
country for him to receive from the
government any reward whatever.’

“It is to be hoped,” Gen. Persh-
ing continues, “that this monument
will be erected, and that the mortal
remains of William H. Dean may
find their final resting place beneath
it. He, also, like Walter Reid, did
not receive any reward from his
country.”
PERSHING'S TRIBUTE TO MARTYR

JOHN J. PERSHING
ASHINGTON
September 6, 1928.

Mr. Edwin F. Sweet,
Kent Hills,
Grand Rapids, Mich.
My dear Mr. Sweet:

I am gratified to have the opportunity to
pay my tribute of respect to that simple Cavalry man,
Private William H. Dean, Troop B, 7th Cavalry, who was
the first of the noble band of volunteers from the ranks
of the American Army in Cuba to suffer an attack of ex-
perimental yellow fever. He was the XY of Major Walter
Reed's Preliminary Note on the transmission of yellow
fever, and, although Dr. Carroll's attack preceded his,
it was thehis case that carried conviction to the minds of
Reed and the other members of the Yellow Fever Board.

It is to be hoped that this monument will be
erected, and that the mortal remains of William H. Dean
may find their final resting place beneath it. He, al-
so, like Walter Reed, did not receive any reward from
his country.

Very sincerely yours.
John J Pershing.
Incl.

Reproduction of a portion of Gen. John J. Pershing's letter to Edwin F. Sweet, paying high tribute to th
courage and sacrifice of Pvt. William H. Dean.
